query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Several actions to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations have been studied. Two studies in Germany found that closing roads during seasonal amphibian migration protected large numbers of amphibians from death [842]. Six out of seven studies in several countries, including Canada, Germany, and the USA, showed that installing culverts or tunnels significantly reduced amphibian road deaths [884]. However, one study found that this was only effective when barrier fencing was also installed [884]. The use of these crossings by amphibians is supported by 15 of 24 studies, which found that 23-100% of culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians [884]. The effectiveness and use of these crossings can be influenced by their design, including diameter, length, lighting, and substrate [884]. Some culvert designs, such as those with one-way tunnels and vertical entry chutes, were found to be unsuitable and resulted in high mortality rates [884]. One study also noted that despite the installation of culverts, thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road [884]. Human assistance for migrating amphibians has also been studied. Despite efforts to move large numbers of amphibians across roads, two studies in Italy and the UK observed population declines of 64-70% over 6-10 years in toad populations that were being assisted [784]. In the UK, one study found that over 500 toads were still killed on roads at 7% of sites with human assistance patrols [784].

One found no effect on road deaths.
Fifteen of 24 studies (including one review and 17 replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that culverts/tunnels were used by amphibians, by 15–85% of amphibians or 3–15 species, or that 23–100% of culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians or used in 12 of 14 studies reviewed. One study found that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road."

query: How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?
relevant_summary:
A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvesting, which encompasses methods like harvesting groups of trees, shelterwood harvesting, and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations compared to clearcutting (844, 851, 852).

When compared to clearcutting, three studies in the USA on harvesting trees in small groups did not find a higher abundance of amphibians or salamanders (844). For shelterwood harvesting, three studies in the USA found that it led to higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance in comparison to clearcutting (851). In the case of thinning, two of four studies in the USA discovered higher amphibian abundance or a less negative overall response in thinned forests, while the other two studies had mixed results depending on the species and time since harvest (852). One study found that emigrating salamanders used thinned forests significantly more than clearcuts (852).

In contrast to unharvested areas, harvesting trees in small groups was found in two US studies to significantly decrease salamander abundance and alter species composition (844). Similarly, two out of three US studies showed that shelterwood harvesting also decreased salamander abundance and changed the composition of species when compared to areas with no harvesting (851). Studies on thinning compared to unharvested forests have shown mixed effects, with some species' abundance increasing while others, like the ensatina salamanders, decreased (852). Another study noted a negative overall response of amphibians to thinning, although one study found that a high volume of pre-existing downed wood helped prevent population declines after thinning (852).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"Impact of different partial harvesting methods vs. clearcutting on salamander populations in USA forests"}

One found a negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians and one found that thinning did not affect abundance. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included thinning with three other types, decreased salamander populations. One controlled, before-and-after site comparison study in the USA found that high volumes of pre-existing downed wood prevented declines in amphibian populations following thinning.
Four studies (including two replicated, controlled studies) in the USA compared amphibians in thinned to clearcut forest. Two found higher amphibian abundance, apart from ensatina salamanders, or a less negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians in thinned forest. One site comparison study in the USA found that thinning decreased the body condition of ensatina salamanders 10 years after harvest."
}

query: What are the potential benefits and harms of controlling fish populations to protect amphibians?
relevant_summary: Studies have found that controlling fish populations can have both benefits and harms for amphibians. One review in Australia, the UK and USA found that fish control, which included using rotenone, increased breeding success for four amphibian species (828). Three studies in Sweden, the UK and USA found that eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance, and recruitment of newt populations (828). However, the use of rotenone can also have negative effects. Two replicated studies in Pakistan and the UK found that when rotenone was applied, many frogs died and a small number of newts showed symptoms of negative effects (828). An alternative to rotenone, a controlled study in Mexico, found that excluding fish using a barrier increased weight gain of axolotls (829).

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of engaging the public in amphibian conservation efforts in Europe and the USA?
relevant_summary: Five studies in Canada, the UK and USA found that amphibian data collection projects engaged 100–10,506 volunteers and were active in 16–17 states in the USA [760]. Five studies in the UK and USA found that volunteers undertook 412 surveys, surveyed 121–7,872 sites, swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians and submitted thousands of amphibian records [760].Two before-and-after studies in Estonia and Taiwan found that habitat management with participation of volunteers increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations [777]. One controlled study in Mexico found that engaging landowners in aquatic habitat management increased axolotl weight [777]. Six studies in Estonia, the USA and UK found that between eight and 41,000 volunteers were engaged in aquatic and terrestrial habitat restoration programmes for amphibians [777]. Individual programmes restored up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km2 of habitat [777].Two studies in Estonia and the UK found that raising public awareness, along with other interventions, increased numbers of natterjack toads and created 1,023 ponds for amphibians [831]. One before-and-after study in Mexico found that raising awareness in tourists, increased their knowledge of axolotls [831]. One study in Taiwan found that holding press conferences to publicize frog conservation had no effect on a green tree frog project [831]. Two studies in Panama and the UK found that awareness campaigns reached over 50,000 members of the public each year or trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years [831].

query: What are the overall success rates for establishing new amphibian populations through translocation or the release of captive-bred individuals?
relevant_summary: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population [854]. An additional two translocations led to breeding, and one resulted in survival after release [854]. A review indicated that translocations involving over 1,000 animals had a higher success rate, and this success was not influenced by the animal source (wild or captive), life stage, continent, or the reason for the translocation [854].

query: As an alternative to direct antifungal treatment of amphibians, what environmental management actions can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: One environmental management action that can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis in amphibians is temperature treatment [770]. Four out of five studies, including four replicated and controlled studies in Australia, Switzerland, and the USA, have shown that raising the enclosure or water temperature to a range of 30–37°C for over 16 hours can cure frogs and toads of the disease [770]. However, one study reported that a heat treatment at 30–35°C for 36 hours was not effective in curing northern leopard frogs [770].

query: When managing understory vegetation in US forests, how does the effectiveness of herbicide use compare to mechanical removal for amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species, but not abundance, were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without [781]. In comparison, one replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that areas where vegetation was treated with herbicides had similar richness of combined reptile and amphibian species compared to areas not treated with herbicide [3712].

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in Australia found that areas where an invasive shrub was sprayed with herbicide had similar composition of reptile species compared to unsprayed areas.
Richness/diversity (3 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies in Australia and the USA found that areas where vegetation was treated with herbicides had similar richness of reptile species or combined reptile and amphibian species compared to areas not treated with herbicide.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): Three of four studies (including three replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Australia found that areas where vegetation was treated with herbicides had similar abundance of all or most reptiles compared to areas not treated with herbicide. Reproductive success (2 studies): One of two controlled studies (including one replicated study and one randomized study) in the USA and US Virgin Islands found that exposure of red-eared slider eggs to high levels of glyphosate caused a reduction in hatching success. Survival (1 studies): One randomized, controlled study in the US Virgin Islands found that in areas treated with herbicide, fewer leatherback turtle hatchlings became entangled in vegetation than in untreated areas.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

query: What does the evidence suggest about the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks, such as species protection laws or financial incentive schemes, for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: Three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development [779]. Two reviews in the UK found that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales [779]. One review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of the over-exploited populations [785, 824]. One study in South Africa found that the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 [785].

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on agricultural lands for amphibian habitats and populations?
relevant_summary:
Five studies in Denmark, Estonia, and the UK found that habitat management that included the reintroduction of grazing increased green toad populations and maintained or increased natterjack and common toad populations (780). Two studies in the USA found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with grazing (746), and one replicated site comparison study in the USA found that ungrazed sites had fewer bog turtles than grazed sites (3512). However, one replicated, controlled study in the UK found that grazed plots had a lower abundance of common toads and did not have a higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots (780). Additionally, a before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads (746). 

Several studies found no significant difference between grazed and ungrazed areas. Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but did increase larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs (746). One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase the number of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (746). A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that ungrazed areas had similar overall reptile and amphibian abundance compared to those that were grazed (3512). One before-and-after study in the USA found that the decline in amphibian species was similar under both traditional season-long and intensive-early cattle stocking (780).

query: What treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis and how effective are they?
relevant_summary: Treatments available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis include antifungal treatments, temperature adjustments, and a combination of fungicide and pond drying [767, 882, 770]. Twelve of sixteen studies found that antifungal treatments cured or increased the survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis [882]. Specifically, treatment with itraconazole was found to be effective in six of eight studies [882]. However, six studies also reported that certain fungicides could lead to death or other negative side effects in amphibians [882]. Another treatment option is temperature adjustment. Four of five studies found that raising the enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of the infection [770]. However, one study on northern leopard frogs did not find this heat treatment to be effective [770]. In a study on wild midwife toads in Mallorca, treating them with a fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate the disease [767].

query: For amphibian conservation in North America, how do the outcomes of creating new wetlands compare to restoring existing wetlands?
relevant_summary:
When creating new wetlands for amphibians in the USA, studies have found mixed results when compared to natural wetlands, with some created wetlands having similar amphibian species numbers and abundance, while others have fewer species or lower abundance (880). The success of created wetlands is influenced by factors such as wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, the presence of fish, and the distance to source wetlands (880). Furthermore, some studies in the USA indicated that certain amphibian species were exclusively found in either created or natural wetlands (880).

One study in the USA that looked at both created and restored wetlands found that together they had amphibian species numbers and abundance that were higher than or similar to natural wetlands (880). Another study in the USA also found that created, restored, enhanced, and natural wetlands had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness (3755). However, a separate before-and-after site comparison in the USA noted that a restored wetland exhibited lower reptile species richness and diversity than an undisturbed wetland (3755).

query: What are the documented impacts of using prescribed fire on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats?
relevant_summary: The impacts of prescribed fire on amphibian populations are varied. Eight of fourteen studies in Australia, North America, and the USA found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or the number of species (877). Four studies found mixed effects on amphibian abundance depending on the species, year, or season of the burn (877). Three studies found that fires increased amphibian abundance or the number of species, while one study found that abundance decreased with fires (877). Two studies in the USA found that the number of amphibian species and their abundance either increased or decreased with time since the prescribed forest fires (877). One before-and-after study in the USA found that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire (877). In a study on wetlands, burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles and amphibians compared to unburned areas (3652). Additionally, one study found that burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas, while another found the richness and diversity to be similar to that of unburned areas (3646). In areas where burning was used in combination with grazing, the overall reptile and amphibian abundance was similar to areas that were only burned or were unmanaged (3657).

Twenty-eight studies evaluated the effects of using prescribed burning in forest, open woodland and savanna on reptile populations. Twenty-four studies were in the USA, three were in Australia and one was in Brazil.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that in areas with prescribed burning, reptile assemblages became similar to more pristine areas that had historically experienced frequent fires.
Richness/diversity (11 studies): Seven studies (including two replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Australia found that burned areas had similar reptile species richness compared to unburned areas. One of the studies also found that burned areas had higher reptile diversity than unburned areas. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in Australia and the USA found that reptile species richness remained similar with time since burning. One of two studies (including one replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study) in the USA found that burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas. The other study found that burned areas had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness and diversity compared to unburned areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (26 STUDIES)

Abundance (23 studies): Nine of 21 studies (including four replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Australia found that burning had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles, six-lined racerunners and western yellow-bellied racer snakes. Six studies found that burned areas had a higher abundance of reptiles, lizards, black racer snakes and more active gopher tortoise burrows compared to unburned areas. The other six studies found that burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles, lizards and gopher tortoise burrows compared to unburned areas. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that reptile abundance increased with time since burning. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that burning in different seasons had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles.
Survival (2 study): One of two studies (one site comparison and one controlled study) in the USA and Brazil found that Texas horned lizard survival was similar in burned and unburned areas. The other study found that burning had mixed effects on survival of an endemic lizard species.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that eastern fence lizards in recently burned areas ran faster than those from areas that were burned less recently or were unburned.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Behaviour change (2 studies): One replicated, controlled, before and-after study in the USA found that burning affected overwintering habitat use by gopher tortoises. query: What is the state of evidence on the effectiveness of removing various types of invasive predators to benefit native amphibians?
relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the USA found that the abundance of squirrel tree frogs and green tree frogs increased after removal of invasive Cuban tree frogs (822). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that removing American bullfrogs significantly increased a population of California red-legged frogs (825). Another study in the USA and Mexico found that eradicating bullfrogs from an area increased the range of leopard frogs (825). The same study found that after bullfrog removal, California red-legged frogs were found out in the open twice as frequently (825). One controlled study in New Zealand found that controlling rats had no significant effect on numbers of Hochstetter’s frog (839). However, another controlled study in New Zealand found that survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in a predator-proof enclosure than in the wild (839). A third study in New Zealand found that at 58% of translocated Hamilton's frogs survived the first year within a predator-proof enclosure (839).

query: How does the success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differ for Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca compared to green and golden bell frogs in Australia?
relevant_summary: In Mallorca, captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites (873). One study in the UK found that while predator defenses were maintained in a reintroduced captive-bred population, genetic diversity was reduced (873). Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads have been successfully raised to metamorphs or toadlets, with one UK study showing an 85% survival rate to metamorphosis (837). However, long-term captive breeding of this species (nine or more generations) has been associated with slower tadpole development, a reduction in one predator defense trait, and decreased genetic diversity (837). In contrast, reintroduction programs for the green and golden bell frog in Australia have had less success. Studies found that captive-bred green and golden bell frogs, released mainly as tadpoles, either did not establish breeding populations or only established them in one out of four release programs (872). Some captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as tadpoles were found to have survived for at least 13 months after release (872). Other studies in Australia showed that a high proportion of captive-bred frogs released as eggs survived to metamorphosis, and there was limited breeding by released frogs (870). Additionally, the removal of viperine snakes in Mallorca led to an increase in the number of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae (830), and the addition of salt to a pond in Australia helped a population of green and golden bell frogs remain free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (762).

query: In Australian captive breeding programs, how do artificial fertilization and hormone treatments compare in their success and challenges for frogs?
relevant_summary: In Australia, hormone treatment of male amphibians has been found to stimulate or increase sperm production, or result in successful captive breeding (883). For female amphibians in Australia, hormone treatment has had mixed results, with 30-71% of females producing viable eggs (883). The success of hormone treatment on female amphibians can also be dependent on the combination, amount or number of doses of hormones (883). Eggs that have been induced by hormone treatment have been raised successfully to tadpoles and froglets in captivity (883). One Australian study found that tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature (835).

Nine studies evaluated the effects on reptile populations of using hormones and/or other drugs during captive-breeding programmes to induce reproduction/birth. Three studies were in each of the USA and New Zealand and one study was in each of the Netherlands, China and Japan.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (9 STUDIES)

Reproductive success (9 studies): Three of four replicated, controlled studies (including one before-and-after study) in the USA and China found that plains gartersnakes, eastern painted turtles and red-eared sliders induced with oxytocin produced a similar percentage of live young compared to individuals that were not induced and laid eggs with similar hatching success or laid a similar number of eggs compared to what was observed in wild nests. The other study found that 25% of eggs from hormone-injected (luteinizing hormone and gonadotropin) four-eyed turtles were fertile, compared to 7–52% for females that were not injected or injected with a saline solution. One study also found mixed effects of different combinations of hormones and other drugs on inducing 13 turtle species. Five studies (including one before-and-after study) in the Netherlands, New Zealand and Japan found that oxytocin, arginine vasotocin and follicle-stimulating hormone induced egg laying/birth in yellow-headed box turtles, tuatara and common geckos or ovulation in hawksbill turtles. Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.

Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."

query: As an alternative to creating new ponds, what species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations at a site?
relevant_summary:
Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population [854]. Translocations of over 1,000 animals were found to be more successful in one review, which also found that success was not related to the source of the animals (wild or captive), their life-stage, the continent, or the reason for the translocation [854].

Twenty-two studies have examined the practice of head-starting amphibians from eggs for release [881]. Six of these ten studies, which included five replicated studies in Denmark, Spain, the UK, and the USA, along with a global review, found that releasing head-started tadpoles, metamorphs, or juveniles led to the establishment of breeding frog populations or an increase in the populations of frogs or toads [881]. Two other studies showed mixed results, with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites [881]. Conversely, two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population [881]. For five of these studies, other interventions like the release of captive-bred individuals, translocation, or habitat management were also implemented [881]. Nine of ten studies, including nine replicated studies in Australia, Canada, Europe, and the USA, reported that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs, or adults successfully metamorphosed, tended to survive the first season, winter, or year, or bred successfully [881]. However, one study found adult survival was 1–17% over four years, and another reported limited breeding after the release of adults [881]. Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK, and the USA discovered that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis were greater, and the time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started animals compared to their wild counterparts [881]. In contrast, one replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild [881].

query: To protect migrating amphibians, how do physical interventions like tunnels and barrier fences compare to closing roads during migration seasons?
relevant_summary: Two studies in Germany found that closing roads during breeding migrations protected large numbers of amphibians from death (842). This was the case at sites with only road closures and at sites that also had assisted crossings and barrier fences (842). Seven of eight studies found that installing barrier fencing along with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths (756). The effectiveness of these barriers can be dependent on the length and material of the fence (756). Some amphibians, such as treefrogs and 10% of common toads, were found to be able to climb over barrier fencing (756). For green frogs and leopard frogs, barriers of at least 0.6 m high were required to prevent them from climbing over (756). One study found that only a low number of amphibians were diverted by barriers (756). In six of seven studies, the installation of culverts or tunnels as road crossings was found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths, although one of these studies noted this was only true when barrier fencing was also installed (884). One study found no effect on road deaths from installing culverts or tunnels (884). Fifteen of twenty-four studies found that culverts and tunnels were used by amphibians, however, five studies found that they were used by less than 10% of amphibians or not used at all (884). The use of culverts and tunnels by amphibians can be affected by their diameter, length, lighting, and substrate (884). Some culvert designs were found to be unsuitable for amphibians, and one study highlighted that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road where tunnels were installed (884).

query: What are the typical outcomes when creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe?
relevant_summary: Studies have shown that creating new ponds can support toad populations in Europe. In Germany, the UK, and the USA, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in 33% of created ponds in one study (868). In Denmark and Switzerland, 29-100% of created ponds were colonized by common and midwife toads (868). Captive-bred garlic toads, however, did not colonize newly created ponds (868). The creation and restoration of ponds, when combined with head-starting, led to an increase in European fire-bellied toad populations in Denmark (868). In Switzerland, midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds (868). For green toads, pond creation along with other interventions was found to significantly increase their populations in Denmark (864). A study in Sweden showed that green toads used 59% of created ponds and reproduced in 41% of them (864). For natterjack toads in the UK and Denmark, pond creation with other interventions led to a significant increase in their populations, or maintained or increased them at 75% of sites (866). A UK study found that created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from invertebrate predation when compared to natural ponds (866).

query: What are some alternatives to clearcutting forests, and what are their documented effects on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: One replicated study in Canada found that red-legged frogs showed no significant movement toward retained tree patches, but larger patches were selected more and moved out of less than small patches [847]. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study [843]. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but the overall response of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained [843]. One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that compared to total clearcutting, leaving dead or wildlife trees did not result in higher abundances of salamanders [845]. Two studies in the USA found that compared to no harvesting, leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent a decrease in salamander abundance or change in species composition [845]. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest [843]. One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance were similar with removal or creation of dead trees within forest [845]. One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed [843]. There is no evidence for the effect of retaining patches of trees rather than clearcutting on amphibian populations [847].

query: What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild?
relevant_summary:
Captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs have been found to establish populations in some cases (875, 873). In one instance, 70% of release sites were populated (875), and for Mallorcan midwife toads, breeding populations were established at 38% to 100% of sites (873). Head-starting amphibians has also been shown to establish or increase populations of frogs and toads. Nine out of ten studies found that head-started amphibians metamorphosed, survived their first season, winter or year, or bred successfully (881). Furthermore, four studies found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater, and time to metamorphosis was shorter in head-started individuals when compared to their wild counterparts (881).

However, there are also documented negative impacts. The release of captive-bred toads did not lead to established populations in one study (875). In Puerto Rico, the survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads was low, with 25% being predated within just two days of release (875). For the Mallorcan midwife toad, a reintroduced population that was captive-bred was found to have reduced genetic diversity (873). Additionally, some studies on head-starting amphibians found that the release of metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population, with one study noting adult survival at a low rate of 1-17% over four years (881). In one Canadian study, young head-started leopard frogs were found to be smaller than those in the wild (881).

Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.

}

query: What actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats on amphibian populations (813). Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but had mixed effects on the abundance of individual species. One before-and-after study in Australia found that restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased frog species (772). One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that providing artificial hibernacula, along with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained populations of great crested newts, and another replicated study in the UK found that created hibernacula were used by common frogs and smooth newts, but not great crested newts. A third replicated study in the UK found four amphibian species close to hibernacula at two of three sites (759). Finally, two studies in New Zealand and the USA found that artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders, although few were used for breeding (772).

query: What factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects?
relevant_summary: Three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population (854). One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful, but that success was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), life-stage, continent or reason for translocation (854). One before-and-after study in Denmark found that translocated garlic toads established breeding populations following pond restoration that included canopy removal (758). Seven studies in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish (869).

Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. query: In the USA, how do partial harvesting techniques like shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting compare in their effects on salamander populations versus clearcutting?
relevant_summary:
In the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance compared to clearcutting (851). In contrast, three studies found that harvesting trees in small groups did not lead to higher amphibian or salamander abundance compared to clearcutting (844). However, a meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvesting, which includes shelterwood, group harvesting, and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (851, 844, 852). When compared to no harvesting, both shelterwood harvesting and harvesting trees in small groups were found to decrease salamander abundance and alter species composition (851, 844). Two studies on thinning found higher amphibian abundance or a less negative overall response in thinned forests compared to clearcut forests (852).

In terms of reproductive effects, one study found that the proportion of female salamanders carrying eggs, the number of eggs per female, and the proportion of juveniles were similar or lower in plots with shelterwood harvesting compared to unharvested plots (851). Similarly, in plots where trees were harvested in groups, the proportion of females with eggs was similar to unharvested plots, while the proportion of eggs per female and juveniles were similar or lower (844).

query: What have been the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations in the USA and UK?
relevant_summary: Three replicated, site comparison studies in the USA found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or their overall abundance (746). However, it did lead to an increase in larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs (746). Conversely, two of these studies found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher in areas with grazing (746). A separate randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA showed that excluding cattle from ponds did not lead to an increase in the number of eggs or the survival of larvae for Columbia spotted frogs (746). In the UK, a before-and-after study indicated that pond restoration, which included the exclusion of livestock, resulted in increased use of the pond by breeding natterjack toads (746).

query: What design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians?
relevant_summary:
The successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians is associated with several design and placement factors. The use of culverts or tunnels as road crossings has been found to significantly decrease amphibian road deaths in six of seven studies (884). For these tunnels to be effective, they often need to be used in conjunction with barrier fencing to guide amphibians to the entrances (884). One study found that barriers need to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent some frog species from climbing over (756).

Several design characteristics of the tunnels themselves have been shown to affect their use by amphibians. Wider culverts were used more in three of six studies, while long culverts were avoided in one of two studies (884). The substrate within the tunnel is also a factor, with natural substrates being used more in three of six studies (884). Other factors that have been studied with mixed effects include lighting, the presence of water, entrance location, and tunnel climate (884). Certain designs have proven to be unsuitable, such as one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes, which led to high mortality in common toads, and steel culverts, from which condensation deposits had very high metal concentrations (884). In one case, raising a road on a viaduct to restore connectivity between two wetlands also significantly decreased the deaths of migrating amphibians (840).

One found no effect on road deaths.

query: In US forests, how do mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation compare in their effects on amphibians?
relevant_summary: In US forests, one randomized, replicated, controlled study found that the number of amphibian species, but not the overall amphibian abundance, was significantly higher in plots where understory vegetation was mechanically removed compared to plots with no removal (781). In contrast, three studies in the USA, including two that were randomized, replicated, and controlled, found that using herbicides to remove understory vegetation had either no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (778).

query: What legal and regulatory actions are available to protect wild amphibian populations from threats like development and trade?
relevant_summary: One review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species led to the recovery of over-exploited populations (785). A study in South Africa noted an increase in permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians from 1987 to 1990 (785). Conversely, three reviews in the Netherlands and the UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective in safeguarding populations during development (779). Two reviews in the UK also reported that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over a 10-year period rose to over 600 in England and Wales (779).

query: For natterjack toad conservation in the UK, what are the documented benefits and negative side effects of adding lime to ponds?
relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the UK showed that adding limestone to ponds led to the establishment of one of three translocated natterjack toad populations, and another UK study found that species-specific habitat management including the addition of limestone increased natterjack toad populations [748]. Adding limestone to ponds was also found to have temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads in one UK before-and-after study, and resulted in metamorphosis of natterjack toads at two of three sites [748]. However, two before-and-after studies in the UK, one of which was controlled, revealed that the addition of limestone to ponds resulted in high tadpole mortality and pond abandonment by natterjack toads [748].

query: To manage chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians, what are the most and least beneficial treatment strategies?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available information, several treatment strategies for chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians have been studied with varying success. Antifungal treatments have been found to be effective in many cases, with twelve out of sixteen studies showing they cured or increased the survival of amphibians with the disease (882). Specifically, the fungicide itraconazole was effective at curing amphibians in six of eight studies (882). Additionally, temperature treatment has shown promise, with four out of five studies demonstrating that increasing the enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis (770).

However, these treatments are not always successful. In four studies, antifungal treatments did not cure the disease but only reduced infection levels or had mixed results (882). Furthermore, some fungicides were found to cause death or other negative side effects in amphibians in six studies (882). One study found that itraconazole only reduced infection levels, and another reported mixed effects (882). Temperature treatment also has its limitations, as one study found that heat treatment did not cure northern leopard frogs (770). Lastly, a study on wild midwife toads found that treating them with a fungicide, in conjunction with pond drying, only reduced infection levels and did not eradicate the chytridiomycosis (767).

query: What are the general outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads, including species like the Mallorcan midwife toad?
relevant_summary:
Two of three studies in Denmark, Sweden, and the USA found that releasing captive-bred toads as tadpoles, juveniles, or metamorphs established populations, with one study finding success at 70% of sites (875). However, another study reported that populations were not established using this method (875). For the Mallorcan midwife toad, three studies in Mallorca found that releasing captive-bred individuals as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults established breeding populations at 38% to 100% of sites (873).

Survival rates can be low, as seen in two Puerto Rican studies where captive-bred crested toads had low survival, and 25% were predated within two days of release (875). In contrast, a review of ten studies on head-started amphibians found that in nine cases, they tended to survive the first season or year and bred successfully (881). Head-starting amphibians has been found to increase populations of toads in some cases, though one study found it did not establish a breeding toad population (881). A study on a reintroduced captive-bred toad population in the UK noted that predator defences were maintained, but there was a reduction in genetic diversity (873).

Twenty-two studies head-started amphibians from eggs and monitored them after release.

Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
Three studies (including one replicated study) in the USA only provided results for head-starting in captivity. Two found that Houston toad eggs could be captive-reared to tadpoles, but only one successfully reared adults. One found that mass, stress levels and survival were not affected by the amount of food or habitat complexity."

query: For road mitigation projects, what design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage?
relevant_summary: Thirty-two studies evaluated the effectiveness of installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings for amphibians (884). Six of seven studies found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths, with one study noting this was true only when barrier fencing was also installed (884). Fifteen of twenty-four studies found that amphibians used culverts or tunnels (884). The use of these passages was affected by several design factors. In some studies, wider culverts were used more, while long culverts were avoided (884). Natural substrates were used more than artificial ones (884). The effects of lighting and the presence of water on usage were mixed (884). Entrance location and tunnel climate were also found to be influencing factors in one study each (884). Conversely, certain designs were found to be unsuitable; for instance, one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes caused high mortality in common toads, and condensation from steel culverts was found to have high concentrations of metal (884). Some studies also reported low usage rates (less than 10%) or no usage at all (884). Even with culverts, one study noted that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road (884).
